questions.text: What is the most commonly fractured bone in cases of basilar skull fractures?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Temporal bone

 

Explanation:

The temporal bone is the most commonly fractured in basilar skull fractures. These fractures can lead to serious complications, including damage to cranial nerves VII (facial nerve) and VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve) and the carotid artery, as well as potential cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks.

 

Thickness of skull bones
 

Male

Female

Frontal

7.8 mm

8.6 mm

Parietal

9.6 mm

10.1 mm

Occipital

10.1 mm

10 mm

Temporal

6 mm

6 mm

 

Temporal bone fracture

Longitudinal Temporal Bone Fracture

Transverse Temporal Bone Fracture
  • The most common type (70-90% of temporal bone fractures).
  • Runs parallel to the long axis of the petrous temporal bone.
  • Otic Capsule is spared.
  • Conductive hearing loss due to ossicle involvement and tympanic membrane involvement.
  • Facial nerve involvement occurs in about 25% of cases.
  • Less common (10-30% of temporal bone fractures).
  • Extends perpendicular to the petrous temporal bone's long axis.
  • Otic Capsule is involved, leading to sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Ossicles and tympanic membranes are generally unaffected.
  • Higher incidence of facial nerve involvement.

 

Occipital bone (Option B), Sphenoid bone (Option C), Frontal bone (Option D): While the occipital, sphenoid, and frontal bones can be involved in basilar skull fractures, they are not as commonly fractured as the temporal bone. Their occurrences are significantly less frequent compared to fractures of the temporal bone.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is a diastatic skull fracture most likely to occur?

choices.text: An adult hit by a broad surface object
A child with increased intracranial pressure
A teenager experiencing a sports-related injury
An elderly person falling onto their buttocks

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) A child with increased intracranial pressure

 

Explanation:

 

Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture)

Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture)

  • The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers.
  • The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force.
  • No depression of bone fragments.
  • Involves the separation of cranial sutures.
  • More common in children.
  • Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures.
  • Commonly seen at the sagittal suture.

Causes:

  • Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents). (Option A ruled out)
  • Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards. (Option D ruled out)

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma to the head.
  • Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation. (Option B)

Narrow fissure skull fracture

 

A teenager experiencing a sports-related injury (Option C): Sports-related injuries typically do not involve sutural separation, which is specific to diastatic fractures.

questions.text: A 32 year old male is brought to the emergency after sustaining a gunshot wound to the head during a robbery. The bullet trajectory is reported as oblique. Which type of skull fracture is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Gutter fracture

 

Explanation:

 

Depressed Fracture

Comminuted Fracture

Gutter Fracture
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks). (Option A ruled out)
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe. (Option D ruled out)
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries). (Option C ruled out)
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound. (Option B)
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

Depressed fracture

Comminuted fracture

Gutter fracture

questions.text: A “motorcyclist fracture," typically results from what type of impact?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Side impact

 

Explanation:

 

Ring Fracture

Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.

Caused by: (Option B, C and D ruled out)

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Often caused by side impacts.

(Option A)


 

Ring fracture

Hinge fracture

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with facial trauma after being struck in the eye during a sports accident. Which radiographic finding is most indicative of a blowout fracture of the orbit?

choices.text: Circular crack around the skull base

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Teardrop sign

 

Explanation:

Blowout fracture is a fracture of the bony orbit (eye socket) resulting from blunt trauma to the eye. It causes fractures to the medial wall and floor of the orbit. The teardrop sign is a significant radiographic finding in blowout fractures, indicating the herniation of orbital soft tissues, such as fat and muscles, into the maxillary sinus. This often leads to pain, restricted eye movements and diplopia.

Blowout fracture of right orbit showing Teardrop sign

 

Spider web-like pattern on X-ray (Option A): The spider web-like pattern on an X-ray is characteristic of comminuted fractures, which involve multiple fracture lines creating a fragmented appearance.

 

Ping-pong ball dent appearance (Option B): The ping-pong ball dent appearance is associated with pond fractures, which occur in infants and young children. This type of fracture is characterised by a smooth, concave indentation in the skull without a distinct fracture line.

 

Circular crack around the skull base (Option D): A circular crack around the skull base is indicative of a ring fracture, which encircles the foramen magnum and is associated with severe trauma.

questions.text: A 45 year old woman falls and strikes the back of her head on the ground. Upon examination, she exhibits signs of a contrecoup injury affecting the frontal lobe. Which of the following statements about her injury is incorrect?

choices.text: The injury results from the brain striking the frontal skull after an initial impact on the occipital region.
Contrecoup injuries are commonly associated with RTAs.
Contrecoup injuries primarily affect the areas directly beneath the point of impact.
The rotational forces during the fall could contribute to the contrecoup mechanism.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Contrecoup injuries primarily affect the areas directly beneath the point of impact.

 

Explanation:

Coup injuries primarily affect the areas directly beneath the point of impact, while contrecoup injuries affect the side opposite the impact.

 

Coup vs. Contrecoup Injuries

Features

Coup

Contrecoup

Definition

Brain injury directly beneath the point of impact.

Brain injury on the side opposite the impact.

Mechanism

Caused by direct impact force.

Occurs when a moving head is suddenly decelerated by hitting a firm surface eg. striking the head on the ground after a fall during RTAs. (Option B ruled out)

Occurrence

More common when a moving object strikes the head.

Common in falls or blows to a stationary head.

Common scenarios

Common in moving head striking an object, e.g., hitting a car dashboard in an accident.

Seen in falls, where the head hits the ground or an unyielding surface, causing injury on the opposite side of the impact.

Organs involved

It can be seen in the brain, heart, spleen and lungs. (More commonly in the brain)

Theories of Contrecoup Injuries:

  • Shear Strain Theory (Holbourn): Brain particles are pulled apart due to rotational forces. (Option D ruled out)
  • Vacuum Theory: A vacuum or cavity forms in the cranial cavity, exerting suction on the brain opposite the point of impact, causing damage.
  • Deceleration Theory: Sudden arrest of the head causes the brain to strike the skull at the opposite pole of impact.

Common scenarios:

  • Occipital impact: Produces frontal contrecoup injury due to brain displacement against the frontal lobes. (Option A ruled out)
  • Temporal or parietal impact: Results in contralateral contrecoup injury on the opposite side of the brain.
  • Top of the head impact: Can cause ventral surface contusion of the cerebral hemisphere.
  • Frontal region impact: May not produce occipital contrecoup injury due to the smooth internal surface of the posterior cranial fossa

questions.text: In the context of intracranial haemorrhages, which of the following statements accurately describes the relationship between the layers of the cranial anatomy and the associated blood vessels?

choices.text: The epidural space contains bridging veins.
The subdural space is located between the pia mater and the arachnoid mater.
The subarachnoid space contains arteries of the circle of Willis.
The middle meningeal artery is located between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The subarachnoid space contains arteries of the circle of Willis

Explanation:
The subarachnoid space is situated between the arachnoid mater and pia mater and contains major arteries, including those of the circle of Willis.

  • This space is usually filled with clear, colourless cerebrospinal fluid.
  • Head trauma or rupture of an intracranial aneurysm causes a subarachnoid haemorrhage (bleeding in the subarachnoid space).
  • The most common specific locations of intracranial aneurysms are at the middle cerebral artery bifurcation and along the anterior communicating artery.

Meningeal layers

Intracranial haemorrhages

  • The first layer is the skull vault (cranium), followed by the dura mater, arachnoid mater, pia mater, and brain tissue (cerebrum).
  • The space between the skull and dura contains the middle meningeal artery.
  • The middle meningeal artery is most prominent at the pterion, the point where the frontal, parietal, sphenoid, and temporal bones meet.

Space

Location

Blood vessel involved

Epidural Space

Between the skull vault and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to epidural hematoma.

Middle meningeal artery

(Option D ruled out)

Subdural Space

Between the arachnoid and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to subdural hematoma. (Option B ruled out)

Bridging veins (which drain into the dural venous sinus)

(Option A ruled out)

Subarachnoid Space

Between the arachnoid and pia mater

Arteries of the circle of Willis (Middle cerebral artery, Anterior communicating artery -most commonly) (Option C)

questions.text: A 25 year old man is brought to the ED after a fall from a height. He was unconscious upon arrival, and a CT scan was done which revealed the following. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rupture of the middle meningeal artery

Explanation:
The CT scan of the patient showing a biconvex accumulation of blood between the skull and dura mater after a fall confirms the diagnosis of EDH. EDH is primarily caused by trauma leading to the rupture of the middle meningeal artery.

Extradural Hemorrhage (Epidural Hemorrhage)

Anatomy: The dura mater is a strong, grey-bluish connective tissue membrane. Its outer layer adheres to the skull, and the inner layer merges with the arachnoid.

Causes:

  • Primarily caused by trauma, resulting in the skull moving relative to the dura and creating an extradural space.
  • Injury Sites: Commonly due to fractures of the squamous temporal bone, leading to injury of the middle meningeal artery (posterior branch).

 

Clinical Features:

  • Initial Symptoms: History of head injury; may include temporary unconsciousness.
  • Lucid Interval: A period (30-40% of cases) after initial unconsciousness where the patient regains awareness, lasting 2-4 hours to a week before neurological symptoms decline.
  • Progression: Increased intracranial pressure can lead to confusion, lethargy, coma, and neurological signs such as contralateral weakness, dilated pupils (initially on the side of haemorrhage), and possible decerebrate rigidity.
  • Fatality: Typically associated with a minimum haemorrhage volume of 100 ml, often due to respiratory failure from brainstem compression.

Imaging: Brain CT scans show a biconvex or lens-shaped mass typical of extradural haemorrhage.

Treatment:

  • Craniotomy: Recommended for acute symptomatic extradural hematomas to facilitate complete hematoma evacuation.
  • Trephination (Burr Hole Evacuation): Employed when advanced surgical expertise is unavailable, serving as a crucial intervention to reduce mortality.

Rupture of bridging veins (Option A): This type of injury is associated with subdural haemorrhage, not extradural haemorrhage, and would not produce a biconvex mass on CT.

Venous thrombosis (Option C): While it can lead to increased intracranial pressure, it does not typically result in a localized biconvex mass, as seen in extradural haemorrhage.

Subarachnoid haemorrhage (Option D): This condition presents with diffuse blood in the subarachnoid space rather than a well-defined mass

questions.text: A forensic pathologist examines a body that has suffered extensive thermal injury. Which of the following characteristics would most likely indicate the presence of a heat hematoma as a postmortem finding?

choices.text: Reddish brown discolouration of the hematoma
Honeycomb appearance of a blood clot

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Honeycomb appearance of a blood clot

 

Explanation:

The honeycomb appearance of a blood clot is indicative of a heat hematoma, which is a specific postmortem finding associated with thermal injuries.

 

A heat hematoma resembles an extradural haemorrhage in appearance and therefore needs to be differentiated from it.

 

Features

Extradural Haematoma

Heat Haematoma

Cause

Trauma to the skull.

Exposure of the head to intense heat leads to charring. (Option C ruled out)

Mechanism

Most commonly due to rupture of the meningeal artery

Shrinkage of meninges and brain, causing brain tissue to ooze out.

Location

Usually adjacent to Sylvian fissure and limited due to dural attachments at the suture line.

Anywhere, usually bilateral.

Distribution

Localised

Diffuse

Trauma signs

Signs of blunt force trauma are present.

Signs of blunt force trauma are absent.

Blood clot

A rubbery, reddish-purple blood clot is seen.

Discoid shape.
  • A soft, friable clot of light chocolate colour is seen. (Option B ruled out)
  • Honeycomb appearance, evenly distributed or sickle-shaped. (Option C)

Carboxyhemoglobin

Absent

Present (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A 65 year old woman presents to the emergency department with confusion and headache that developed gradually over the past two weeks after a minor fall. A CT scan reveals an isodense lesion along the cerebral convexities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subacute Subdural Hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

The gradual onset of symptoms and isodense appearance on CT are characteristic of subacute subdural haemorrhage, typically occurring days to weeks after injury.

Subdural Haemorrhage

  • Anatomy:
    • Subdural space is narrow, between the dura mater and arachnoid.
    • Cerebral (bridging) veins cross this space to reach venous sinuses.
  • Causes: Rupture of parasagittal bridging veins or inferior cerebral veins.
  • Occurrence:
    • Common in children, the elderly, alcoholics, or those with brain atrophy.
    • Occurs from minor trauma, often without fractures.
    • Seen in falls, vehicle accidents, or assaults.

 

Acute SDH

Subacute SDH

Chronic SDH
  • Rapid onset after trauma
  • Rupture of large bridging veins or cortical arteries.
  • The most common symptoms are mental confusion, drowsiness, dilation of the pupil (ipsilateral) and contralateral involvement of hemiparesis.
  • Death may occur if the haemorrhage volume is about 100 to 150 ml.
  • Hyperdense on CT. (Option A ruled out)
  • Symptoms develop over days to weeks after injury.
  • Usually from smaller bridging veins.
  • Isodense on CT
  • Develops weeks or months later
  • Often in the elderly;
  • Slow bleeding leads to gradual symptoms.
  • Symptoms arise weeks/months later;
  • May lead to Subdural Hygroma:-Tear in the arachnoid allows CSF to collect in the subdural space, causing cerebral compression.
  • Hypodense on CT (Option C ruled out)
  • CT Findings:
    • Crescentic (crescent moon-shaped, concave, banana-shaped) appearance.
    • More extensive than epidural haemorrhage (EDH), covering a larger area.
  • Treatment:
    • Decompression surgery

Epidural Hematoma (Option D): This diagnosis is unlikely because epidural hematomas typically appear as biconvex (lens-shaped) lesions on CT, rather than the crescentic shape seen in subdural haemorrhages.

questions.text: A 50 y/o man is found unconscious in his home after complaining of severe headache. A CT of the patient is given below. His medical history is significant for hypertension and smoking. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ruptured berry aneurysm

 

Explanation:

The CT scan shows evidence of subarachnoid haemorrhage, which is characterised by bleeding into the space between the brain and the meninges. It shows a classical star sign.

 

The most common cause of subarachnoid haemorrhage is a ruptured aneurysm, particularly a berry aneurysm. The patient's age, history of hypertension, and smoking are all risk factors for developing aneurysms.

 

Subarachnoid Haemorrhage (SAH):

Bleeding into the subarachnoid space (between the arachnoid and pia mater) which is normally filled with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Causes of SAH:

 

Traumatic Causes

Non-traumatic Causes
  • Head trauma (m/c)
  • Cerebral contusions or lacerations
  • Explosive blasts
  • Asphyxia by strangulation
  • Traumatic asphyxia
  • Blows to the neck
  • Accidents and falls
  • Cervical manipulations (e.g., vertebral or basilar arteries)
  • Rupture of traumatic intracerebral haemorrhage (ICH)
  • Prolonged hyperextension of the head during bronchoscopy
  • Ruptured berry aneurysm (saccular aneurysm) (m/c)
  • Arteriovenous malformations
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Leaking intracerebral haemorrhage
  • Purpuric states
  • Leukaemia

 

Signs & Symptoms:

  • Sudden, severe "thunderclap headache" (reaches peak intensity within a minute).
  • Nausea and vomiting.
  • Neck stiffness, photophobia, drowsiness, or agitation.
  • Depressed consciousness.
  • Key findings on examination: Meningism and positive Kernig's sign.

 

Diagnosis:

  • First line: Non-contrast CT scan (shows hyperdense blood collections along falx, basilar cisterns).
  • Second line: Lumbar puncture (if CT is inconclusive) – shows blood-mixed CSF under increased pressure.

 

Medico-legal Aspects:

  • Trauma-induced rupture: Can determine if trauma caused or contributed to berry aneurysm rupture (especially with acute neurological symptoms after injury).
  • Vessel condition: Older individuals with atherosclerosis and hypertension have a higher rupture risk.
  • Postmortem SAH: This can occur due to decomposition, requiring careful examination to distinguish from ante-mortem haemorrhage.

 

Trauma from a fall (Option B): No trauma history is mentioned, making this less likely compared to an aneurysm rupture.

 

Hypertensive encephalopathy (Option C): Hypertensive encephalopathy typically causes diffuse cerebral oedema and other changes, not isolated subarachnoid haemorrhage. The site is usually putamen which is the most common site of hypertensive bleed.

 

Acute subdural haematoma (Option D): Subdural haematomas usually result from head trauma and appear differently on imaging compared to SAH.

questions.text: A retired boxer presents with a gradual decline in his coordination, memory, and speech over the past few years. His wife reports personality changes, including paranoia and social withdrawal. O/E, he displays dysarthria and broad-based gait. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dementia pugilistica

 

Explanation:

The patient’s history of repeated head trauma (boxing), along with symptoms like incoordination, memory loss, personality changes, dysarthria and broad-based gait, is characteristic of punch-drunk syndrome (dementia pugilistica).

 

Punch-Drunk Syndrome:

Also known as dementia pugilistica or boxer's encephalopathy, it results from repeated cerebral concussions, typically in boxers.

 

Signs and Symptoms:

  • Deterioration of speed and reflexes
  • Incoordination
  • Personality changes (social instability, paranoia, delusions)
  • Memory loss (progressing to dementia)
  • Parkinsonian signs:
    • Ataxia or intention tremors
    • Shuffling, broad-based gait
    • Dysarthria (difficulty speaking)

 

Autopsy findings:

  • Chronic subdural haematoma (SDH)
  • Attenuation of the corpus callosum
  • Diffuse axonal injury (DAI)
  • Cortical atrophy

Parkinson's disease (Option A): Although Parkinson's disease shares some features like tremors and gait disturbances, this patient has a history of boxing and repeated head trauma, which makes punch-drunk syndrome more likely.

 

Alzheimer's disease (Option B) is primarily associated with memory loss and cognitive decline but the history of boxing and gait disturbances differentiate punch drunk syndrome from it.

 

Multiple sclerosis (Option D) can cause motor and cognitive symptoms but is less likely given the patient's history and specific symptoms linked to repeated head trauma.

questions.text: A 65 year old man with a history of hypertension presents to the ED with a sudden onset of weakness in his right arm and leg. He also complains of a severe headache and nausea. On examination, he has a decreased level of consciousness and right-sided hemiparesis. A CT scan shows a hyperdense lesion in the left basal ganglia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage

 

Explanation:

The patient has a history of hypertension and the CT findings (hyperdense lesion in the basal ganglia) are typical of hypertensive ICH, which commonly affects the basal ganglia. Putamen is the most common site of hypertensive bleeding.

Intracerebral Haemorrhage (ICH): ICH refers to bleeding within the brain parenchyma, distinct from surface bleeding.

 

Causes of ICH: The most common cause is hypertension.

Clinical Features:

  • Sudden onset of focal neurological deficit
  • Decreased consciousness
  • Signs of raised intracranial pressure (vomiting, headache)
  • Contralateral hemiparesis
  • Seizures are rare

 

Diagnosis:

  • CT scan: ICH appears as a hyperdense lesion
  • Comparison with other haemorrhages:
    • EDH: Biconvex, lenticular (Option A ruled out)
    • SDH: Crescentic (Option D ruled out)
    • SAH: Hyperdense along the falx and basilar cisterns (Option B ruled out)

 

EDH

SDH

SAH
